text: Thakin Ba Thein Tin (, 1914-1995) was a Burmese communist and the chairman of Communist Party of Burma (CPB) from 1975 to 1989. Born in Tavoy, his father was a Chinese petty trader, his mother was a Burmese. In 1931, he passed the matriculation exam and attended Rangoon University. However, he was unable to further his studies because his debt-ridden father could not afford university fees. Ba Thein Tin became a worker for the Dohbama Asiayone in 1938, and joint the CPB in the next year, he was one of the earliest CPB members. As the district party committee organizer in Tavoy, he fought against Japanese in 1945. He became a politburo member of CPB in the next year. In March 1948, he went underground with Thakin Than Tun. He was selected the vice chairman in 1950. In 1953, he left for China and resided there. Since mid-1960s he became the de facto leader of CPB. After the assassination of , Ba Thein Tin was selected the chairman in May 1975, and continued fighting against Burma government. However, he did not return from China until 1978. In April 1989, a group of CPB mutineers raided the party headquarters in the border town of Panghsang. Ba Thein Tin and many senior party members were deported to China. He died in Changsha, Hunan Province in 1995. ==See also== *Communist insurgency in Myanmar ==References== Category:1914 births Category:1995 deaths Category:Communist Party of Burma politicians Category:People from Tanintharyi Region Category:University of Yangon alumni
